venue.name.bold: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE

individual.title.title.segment: MENLO ENERGY, LLC, et al., Defendants.

content.judge.judge.line: JOHN E. DOWDELL UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE

para.paratext: Before the Court is plaintiff's motion to dismiss the fraud claim in defendants' “Amended Counterclaims.” Plaintiff acknowledges that, following the filing of its prior dismissal motion, which was based upon Fed. R. Civ. P. 9(b) and 12(b)(6), the defendants' amendment “arguably cured the lack of specificity ․ by adding allegations concerning the who, what and where of the alleged fraud.” (Doc. 24 at 2). However, plaintiff argues that defendants' additional allegations in the amended fraud claim do not “imbue it with any sense of plausibility,” and plaintiff accordingly moves again under Rule 12(b)(6).

In considering a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the court must determine whether defendants' pleading states a claim upon which relief may be granted. Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6). A pleading must provide “more than labels and conclusions, and a formulaic recitation of the elements of a cause of action.” Bell Atlantic Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 555 (2007). The standard requires “enough facts to state a claim to relief that is plausible on its face,” and the factual allegations “must be enough to raise a right to relief above the speculative level.” Id. at 555-56, 570 (citations omitted). Twombly articulated the pleading standard for all civil actions. See Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 684 (2009). The Court must accept all the well-pleaded factual allegations of the defendants' counterclaim as true, even if doubtful, and must construe the allegations in the light most favorable to defendants. See Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555.

Plaintiff urges that the scheme alleged by defendants in their fraud counterclaim “simply makes no sense.” (Doc. 24). While the Court acknowledges that the misrepresentation allegedly made by plaintiff would seem to more closely fit within a warranty theory than a fraud theory, the Court must assume that the factual allegations in the challenged pleading are true, “even if doubtful in fact.” Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555. Accordingly, the Court accepts as true the defendants' allegations that: (1) in order to induce Menlo Energy to enter into the Master Agreement, plaintiff falsely represented that the railcars being offered were suitable for Menlo Energy's uses; (2) the representation was material in that it actually induced Menlo Energy to enter into a long-term agreement with plaintiff, requiring years of continuing rental payments on the railcars; (3) plaintiff made the representation falsely or recklessly; (4) Menlo Energy reasonably relied on the false representation; and (5) Menlo Energy was injured as a result. Those allegations state a plausible counterclaim for fraud at the pleading stage.
IT IS THEREFORE ORDERED that plaintiff's motion to dismiss (Doc. 24) the fraud counterclaim is denied.
SO ORDERED this 31st day of March, 2016.
